Coconut Tofu Stir-Fry Recipe | Bon Appétit

The green beans cook fast—we’re talking 3 minutes—and achieve my ideal tender-yet-crisp happy place. Here the beans are seasoned with a spicy Southeast Asian–inspired sauce that counters the slightly sweet coconutty tofu. The fish sauce is optional but highly recommended. —Sarah JampelAll products featured on Bon Appétit are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through the retail links below, we earn an affiliate commission.What you’ll needChevronChevronLarge Nonstick Skillet$50 At AmazonCitrus Juicer$7 At AmazonCutting Board$10 At IKEAChef's Knife$34.53 At AmazonKitchen Towels$22 At AmazonRimmed Baking Sheet$20 At Bon Appétit MarketIngredients2–4 servings114-oz. block extra-firm tofuKosher salt1Tbsp. plus 1½ tsp. sambal oelek1Tbsp. plus 1½ tsp. soy sauce or tamari2tsp. light or dark brown sugar1tsp. fish sauce (optional)1lime8oz. green beans2garlic cloves11" piece ginger1bunch basil3Tbsp. vegetable oil, divided¼cup unsweetened shredded coconutShort-grain or jasmine rice (for serving)PreparationStep 1Drain one 14-oz. block extra-firm tofu and slice ½" thick. Arrange in a single layer on a kitchen towel set on a rimmed baking sheet or dry cutting board. Season lightly with kosher salt. Wrap towel over tofu like you’re tucking it in and press to expel some moisture. Set aside.Play/Pause ButtonPausePlay/Pause ButtonPauseChevronChevronStep 2Mix 1 Tbsp. plus 1½ tsp. sambal oelek, 1 Tbsp. plus 1½ tsp. soy sauce or tamari, 2 tsp. light or dark brown sugar, 1 tsp. fish sauce (if using), and 1 Tbsp. water in a small bowl to combine. Cut 1 lime in half; squeeze juice from 1 half into sambal mixture and stir again; set aside. Cut remaining lime half into wedges and set aside for serving.Step 3Trim 8 oz. green beans and cut into ¼" pieces. Peel 2 garlic cloves and coarsely chop. Then peel one 1" piece ginger and coarsely chop. Very coarsely chop basil leaves from 1 bunch basil to measure 1 loosely packed cup. Set green beans, garlic, ginger, and basil aside.Play/Pause ButtonPausePlay/Pause ButtonPauseChevronChevronStep 4Heat 2 Tbsp. vegetable oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high. Unwrap reserved tofu and arrange in pan in a single layer. Cook, undisturbed, until golden brown underneath, about 4 minutes. Turn over and cook until other sides are golden brown, about 4 minutes. Sprinkle ¼ cup unsweetened shredded coconut over tofu and cook, turning often to prevent burning, until tofu is coated and coconut is toasted, about 2 minutes. Transfer to a rimmed baking sheet; season lightly with salt.Play/Pause ButtonPausePlay/Pause ButtonPauseChevronChevronStep 5Heat remaining 1 Tbsp. vegetable oil over medium-high. Add reserved green beans and toss to coat; season lightly with salt. Cook, stirring, 30 seconds. Reduce heat to  medium, add 1 Tbsp. water, and cover pan. Cook until beans are crisp-tender, about 3 minutes. Uncover pan and add reserved garlic and ginger. Cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Return tofu to pan and add reserved sambal mixture. Cook, tossing gently, until sauce is nearly evaporated, about 30 seconds. Taste stir-fry and season with more salt if needed. Remove from heat and gently toss in reserved basil.Play/Pause ButtonPausePlay/Pause ButtonPausePlay/Pause ButtonPauseChevronChevronStep 6Divide short-grain or jasmine rice among bowls; top with stir-fry. Serve with reserved lime wedges for squeezing over.Play/Pause ButtonPausePlay/Pause ButtonPauseChevronChevronHow would you rate Coconut Tofu Stir-Fry?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (14)Back to TopTriangleDELICIOUS!! doubled the sauce as recommended. added toasted coconut with the basil to avoid scorching. cant wait to eat it again.marcy3/7/2022Did not have green beans or basil on hand; used sliced mushrooms and it was absolutely delicious. Thank you
SarinesNewport, RI3/7/2022We LOVE this recipe. I've made so many Bon Appetit recipes and my partner said this was her absolute favorite. Instead of sambal, I used half gochujang, half sriracha. I think the fish sauce IS necessary. It was wonderful, not too hard (esp with two working on it) and it definitely delivered. Vietnamese/Malaysian vibes. So good!!! Kara T.Atlanta, GA12/3/2021It's always fun to find a new way to cook tofu!  We make this without the sambal oelek because I'm avoiding peppers.  It's still good.  Anonymous10/30/2021This was good, with notes. As predicted, the coconut burned immediately upon hitting the pan, so next time I might heat that separately, but I also don't think it added much coconut flavor. Maybe coconut milk to the sauce would work, or coconut rice. I also doubled the sauce, because I love sauce, and even then it quickly evaporated. I thought the flavor of the sambal olek was delicious. I added the fish sauce because I love it. Will make again!nilssons9/29/2021My boyfriend and I have been trying to incorporate more non-meat dishes into our repertoire, and this coconut tofu stir fry is going to become one of our new favorites. It was worth tracking down the Sambal Oelek because the sauce is SO good. While I loved this recipe, I think the only thing it is missing is a crunch element (the coconut doesn't cut it for me). The next time I make this, I'm going to add more fresh lime before serving, and possibly throw some chopped scallions or crunchy onion bits on top. Also, be careful, coconut flakes can burn very quickly if you don't keep your eyes on them!DanielleWashington, D.C.9/16/2021A keeper recipe! Add one Thai chili for a buzzy mouthfeel. Didn't have coconut flakes, but used coconut oil for the slightly nutty flavoring.MaddieToronto, ON9/10/2021Absolutely loved this! Didn’t change a thing. Better than the last Chinese food I bought. The sauce is excellent and the tofu makes you forget it is a meatless dish. Definite keeper that I will put on the rotation.AnonymousMiddletown NY9/7/2021I'm clearly making this again! The tofu was nice to have as a low-fat protein option, but the sauce, lime and basil really made the beans pop. Might need to add more coconut next time because the flavor was lost but in the end I didn't miss it. Makes for a light lunch or dinner.Ava9/5/2021Genuinely did not expect this to turn out as good as it did. Only mods I made: I have super dark soy sauce so cut back that amount, used a TBS instead of water when steaming the beans, and added some coconut cream to the sauce in lieu of flakes as I hate the texture. Very well balanced. BilliePittsburgh, PA9/5/2021I’ve completely ruined the issue that has this recipe in it from making it so many times. One refinement I make is to add some black sugar to the coconut and toast it in the flash fried and then add it to the top during plating. I  also sprinkle a few fried shallots and sesame seeds on top. I loved serving this dish with the watermelon and snap pea salad. I use snow peas instead and add Korean soybean spouts.KarenAugusta, Georgia8/27/2021I substituted sweet peppers because string beans were the only thing I didn’t have in the house! It’s delicious!  Absolutely delicious & delightful & flavorful recipe I am making it again with the string beans in a few days!  Juliet PanebiancoFlorida 8/27/2021This sounded good when I read the recipe but it was even more delicious than I expected! The heat, salt and acid (with an extra squirt of lime for serving) were really well balanced. I made it exactly as written but might try it with a little less oil just to cut down the fat calories. (It didn't taste "fatty.") I will definitely make it again!JulianSanta Cruz, CA8/26/2021Delicious! Made for myself and for my boyfriend (24m). We both loved it and there is enough leftover for lunch for me tomorrow. I would suggest turning down the stove a bit when you add the sambal mixture.
